message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Kawasaki disease, a type of vasculitis. Without proper treatment, the patient is at increased risk of developing coronary artery ectasia, an abnormal dilation of the coronary arteries. Other options are not typically associated with Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Kawasaki disease. If not treated appropriately, the patient is at increased risk of developing coronary artery ectasia, which is dilation or widening of the coronary arteries leading to aneurysm formation and subsequent thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death. Acute renal failure, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and pulmonary embolism are not typically associated with Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, along with the presence of strawberry tongue and perianal erythema, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease. If not treated appropriately, Kawasaki disease can lead to the development of coronary artery ectasia, which is an enlargement of the coronary arteries and can result in life-threatening complications such as myocardial infarction. Acute renal failure, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and pulmonary embolism are not typically associated with Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is displaying symptoms of Kawasaki disease, which is an acute illness that mainly affects children under the age of five. Coronary artery ectasia is a potential complication of Kawasaki disease, which can lead to the formation of aneurysms in the coronary arteries. If left untreated, this can increase the risk of myocardial infarction or sudden death. Acute renal failure, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and pulmonary embolism are not known complications of Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Kawasaki disease, which can cause coronary artery damage due to inflammation. Acute renal failure, lower GI hemorrhage, and pulmonary embolism are not commonly associated with Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical examination findings suggest Kawasaki disease. If not treated appropriately, Kawasaki disease can lead to the development of coronary artery ectasia and aneurysms, making option (B) the correct answer. Acute renal failure is not a common complication of Kawasaki disease, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage is possible but less common, and pulmonary embolism is not typically associated with this disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the patient has Kawasaki disease. If left untreated, Kawasaki disease can cause the complication of coronary artery ectasia (dilation of coronary arteries), leading to hypertension, myocardial infarction, and death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of Kawasaki disease, which can lead to the development of coronary artery aneurysms or ectasia if left untreated. The other complications listed are not typical of Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest that the patient has Kawasaki disease. If not treated appropriately, the patient is at increased risk of developing coronary artery abnormalities, including ectasia and aneurysms. Acute renal failure, lower gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and pulmonary embolism are not typically associated with Kawasaki disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest Kawasaki disease, which is associated with coronary artery abnormalities and can lead to coronary artery ectasia. The other options are not typically associated with Kawasaki disease.
